19:.

Hall Elected To
Head Y. M.C. A.
W. Purnell Hall, Jr., was
elected President of the Johns
Hopkins Y. AC C. A. for 192829 at the annual elections
which were held last week.
The other officers elected are:
John Markle, Vice-President,
Stanley Lausch, Secretary, and
George Dowell, Treasurer. At
the last Cabinet Meeting Clark
Wisotszki was appointed editor and William Olsen business manager of the Handbook for next year.

KOLB AND WOOD TO
HEAD BLUE JAY
13ennet Kolb was elected
editor-in-chief of next year's
Black and Blue Jay at the
publication's
banquet last
night. Richard Wood was
chosen business manager at
the same time.
Much of the success of the
Jay this year has been due to
the editor-in-chief and business manager elect. These
two men have worked hard
for the Jay, Kolb for two
years and Wood since his
election last year.
Kolb and Wood will not
take office till next year, as the
present board of- control will
hold the reins for the rest of
this term.

EDITORIAL COMMENT
LET'S GIVE A RAH
FOR JOHNNY HOPKINS

dergraduates who prefer to sit in the
concrete stands instead of the cheering section even when they are not
escorting girls? Are the wooden
benches too uncomfortable for these
men or is it just a desire to hold aloof
from the "common herd"?
Let's regain ,consciousness before
the big games and give the team the
support it deserves
G.0.

Nothing to do and no one around
oftimes such a combination is welcome, indeed. Moody, you know. A
bit blue after the last tilt with her,
or after things have gone wrong.
Brooding, thinking, treading the
far-reaching expanse of the mind.
But ofttimes, nothing to do and no
one around. Alone when even the
sound of a familiar voice is as welcome as the full-throated song of
the first harbingers of spring to a
snow-bound world. The taunting,
jeering, maddening, never-ending
monotone of an alarm clock seems
to keep time with each second as it
crawls by. To think—'tis to invite
madness. Read? My God! Throw
the damned book away! I want
ACTION!
We all have suffered such lapses
before. How we terminate them or
given vent to our stifled emotions
may differ. The telephone is always
a refuge. She or him—more often
she. The blare of a jazz orchestra;
the wail of the saxophone; rat-a-tattat and bam! bang! on the drums;
shouts, laughter, the sickening odor
of cheap perfume mingled with that
of whiskey and a heavy pall of
smoke over all; shuffling of feet.
Rat-a-tat-tat, bang! barn! the haunting wail of the saxophone and the
brass-throated flare of the trombone.
Dance! Music! Make merry and
away with care! Rat-a-tat-tat, bang!
bam ! and the cry of the saxophone
and the trombone.

writing. Pen or pencil covers page
after page of paper; pencils become
unmanageable, stubs and pens go
dry; my fingers finally grow weary
and I go to bed. But Allah have
mercy on all poor readers of the
drivel I turn out in such moods—as
the above, and whatever may follow.

NIGHT ON THE SOUND
A silver crescent mounts the bluegrey dome,
Fast darkening, to the east,
And bids the setting sun adieu.
Grey clouds in billows
Serenely make their way across the
sky,
Grow rose-tinted as
Retiring Apollo's parting rays
Suffuse them.
Topaz fades to grey—then black,
And forms the setting of a myriad
precious stones
That blazon forth.
An early comer in the west soon
vanishes.

A vast illimitable silence
Reigns over marsh and shallow
pools of stagnant water;—
A silence

Charleston, S. C.
February 10, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.,
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
I've done a lot of pipe smoking.
There's hardly a brand or a blend that
I haven't tried out at some time or
other.
But speaking of smoking tobacco
that brings real enjoyment, and never
changes, I want to say that there is
just one tobacco that gives me real
enjoyment in my pipe—Edgeworth.
I have used Edgeworth Ready
Rubbed and Plug Slice for over five
years, in all climates and under all
conditions, and I find it always the
same. It is always mellow and moist,
and its genuine flavor lasts. There is
no bite or parch in Edgeworth, and the
quality, whether you buy it in small
or large quantities, is always perfect.
Thanks to the manufacturers for
their wonderful product, and I hope
that Edgeworth can always be obtainable by the undersigned.
Guy B. Beatty

PHOTOGRAPHIC DIRECTOR

WALTER SCHEIDT, 'SO

_Md., April 20, 1928.

HOPKINS CRUSHES HUSKY LAFAYETTE TWELVE
The Black and Blue proved to its most pessimistic fol, •
lowers that it is in a fair way headed for another national
title and Olympic honors when it buried a brawny Lafay.
ette lacrosse outfit under an avalanche of goals at Home,
wood last Saturday. The final score was 15 to 2.

CAPTAIN OF HOPKINS TRACK
TEAM SHINES IN MEET
Captain Vivell nailed three first
places in the meet with Gettysburg
last Saturday at Homewood when the
Jay team trounced their visitors in a
dual meet, 30 to 46.

FATHER BILL, MASTER COACH
Mr. William Schmeisser, veteran
coach- of Johns Hopkins lacrosse
teams, is working hard to produce a
third consecutive champion club this
spring with the aid of Head Coach
Ray Van Orman.

POINTING THE WAY TO ANOTHER TITLE
Captain Carroll Leibcnsperger of the Hopkins
lacrosse team is. playing his fourth and last season
at point for the great Black and Blue outfit. If he
can lead his team through the season undefeated, it
is more than possible that Hopkins will represent
America in the Olympic games this summer.

Dr. Goodnow To Be
Honorary Presidency

Still Unsettled
Dr. Frank J. Goodnow will be
the guest of honor at the annual
dinner of the New York Alumni
Association of the Johns Hopkins
University to be held Tuesday,
April 10, at the Commodore Hotel,
New York City:
The affair is in the form of a
testimonial dinner to Dr. Goodnow,
in view of his recent resignation as
president of the university.

Ballots for the election of honorary president of the Senior Class
may be found in today's NEWS-LETTER. Dr. Mitchell and Professor
Christie are the two nominees for
this office.
Professor Christie is head of the
Mechanical Engineering School,
while Dr. Mitchel is in the College
of Arts and Sciences. The first election was a tie and a second was
called Wednesday; but due to the
small number of Seniors who attended, Ridgley Warfield decided to
run a ballot in today's issue of the
NEWS-LETTER.

Plans have been developed with
the spirit of expressing an appropriate tribute to Dr. Goodnow,
whose regime as president of the

ment of the university.

EDITORIAL COMMENT
LET'S GIVE A RAH
FOR JOHNNY HOPKINS

dergraduates who prefer to sit in the
concrete stands instead of the cheering section even when they are not
escorting girls? Are the wooden
benches too uncomfortable for these
men or is it just a desire to hold aloof
from the "common herd"?
Let's regain ,consciousness before
the big games and give the team the
support it deserves
G.0.

Nothing to do and no one around
oftimes such a combination is welcome, indeed. Moody, you know. A
bit blue after the last tilt with her,
or after things have gone wrong.
Brooding, thinking, treading the
far-reaching expanse of the mind.
But ofttimes, nothing to do and no
one around. Alone when even the
sound of a familiar voice is as welcome as the full-throated song of
the first harbingers of spring to a
snow-bound world. The taunting,
jeering, maddening, never-ending
monotone of an alarm clock seems
to keep time with each second as it
crawls by. To think—'tis to invite
madness. Read? My God! Throw
the damned book away! I want
ACTION!
We all have suffered such lapses
before. How we terminate them or
given vent to our stifled emotions
may differ. The telephone is always
a refuge. She or him—more often
she. The blare of a jazz orchestra;
the wail of the saxophone; rat-a-tattat and bam! bang! on the drums;
shouts, laughter, the sickening odor
of cheap perfume mingled with that
of whiskey and a heavy pall of
smoke over all; shuffling of feet.
Rat-a-tat-tat, bang! barn! the haunting wail of the saxophone and the
brass-throated flare of the trombone.
Dance! Music! Make merry and
away with care! Rat-a-tat-tat, bang!
bam ! and the cry of the saxophone
and the trombone.

writing. Pen or pencil covers page
after page of paper; pencils become
unmanageable, stubs and pens go
dry; my fingers finally grow weary
and I go to bed. But Allah have
mercy on all poor readers of the
drivel I turn out in such moods—as
the above, and whatever may follow.

A silver crescent mounts the bluegrey dome,
Fast darkening, to the east,
And bids the setting sun adieu.
Grey clouds in billows
Serenely make their way across the
sky,

Retiring Apollo's parting rays

Topaz fades to grey—then black,

precious stones

vanishes.

pools of stagnant water;—

WALTER SCHEIDT, 'SO

_Md., April 20, 1928.

HOPKINS CRUSHES HUSKY LAFAYETTE TWELVE
The Black and Blue proved to its most pessimistic fol, •
lowers that it is in a fair way headed for another national
title and Olympic honors when it buried a brawny Lafay.
ette lacrosse outfit under an avalanche of goals at Home,
wood last Saturday. The final score was 15 to 2.

CAPTAIN OF HOPKINS TRACK
TEAM SHINES IN MEET
Captain Vivell nailed three first
places in the meet with Gettysburg
last Saturday at Homewood when the
Jay team trounced their visitors in a
dual meet, 30 to 46.

FATHER BILL, MASTER COACH
Mr. William Schmeisser, veteran
coach- of Johns Hopkins lacrosse
teams, is working hard to produce a
third consecutive champion club this
spring with the aid of Head Coach
Ray Van Orman.

POINTING THE WAY TO ANOTHER TITLE
Captain Carroll Leibcnsperger of the Hopkins
lacrosse team is. playing his fourth and last season
at point for the great Black and Blue outfit. If he
can lead his team through the season undefeated, it
is more than possible that Hopkins will represent
America in the Olympic games this summer.

convention in Columbus, Ohio,
from April 25 to April 28. But
owing to the fact that he is also to
represent Hopkins in the regional
semi-finals of the National Oratorical Contest at Western Maryland College on April 27 he may

unable to complete definite plans.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 20, 1928

Dr. Goodnow To Be
Honorary Presidency
Guest of Alumni
Still Unsettled
Dr. Frank J. Goodnow will be
the guest of honor at the annual
dinner of the New York Alumni
Association of the Johns Hopkins
University to be held Tuesday,
April 10, at the Commodore Hotel,
New York City:
The affair is in the form of a
testimonial dinner to Dr. Goodnow,
in view of his recent resignation as
president of the university.

Ballots for the election of honorary president of the Senior Class
may be found in today's NEWS-LETTER. Dr. Mitchell and Professor
Christie are the two nominees for
this office.
Professor Christie is head of the
Mechanical Engineering School,
while Dr. Mitchel is in the College
of Arts and Sciences. The first election was a tie and a second was
called Wednesday; but due to the
small number of Seniors who attended, Ridgley Warfield decided to
run a ballot in today's issue of the
NEWS-LETTER.

Plans have been developed with
the spirit of expressing an appropriate tribute to Dr. Goodnow,
whose regime as president of the

ment of the university.
